description:
Fix a static initializer regression.

BUG=94925
TBR=gcasto

Committed: https://src.chromium.org/viewvc/chrome?view=rev&revision=224020

messages.text: We don't accept these regressions. Had this been more complicated, I would have reverted.

CQ is trying da patch. Follow status at
https://chromium-status.appspot.com/cq/thakis@chromium.org/23891006/1

On 2013/09/19 02:02:41, Nico wrote:
> We don't accept these regressions. Had this been more complicated, I would have
> reverted.

I had a conversation about this with kkania earlier when it was first reverted. He said that it was okay to revert the revert and fix. My fix  was cl/23536069, which I guess I should have committed manually instead of going through the commit queue, my apologies. BTW, is there any documentation about things like this (don't use <iostream>?). It's pretty annoying to get reverted even after passing all the trybots.

On Wed, Sep 18, 2013 at 8:08 PM, <gcasto@chromium.org> wrote:

> On 2013/09/19 02:02:41, Nico wrote:
>
>> We don't accept these regressions. Had this been more complicated, I would
>>
> have
>
>> reverted.
>>
>
> I had a conversation about this with kkania earlier when it was first
> reverted.
> He said that it was okay to revert the revert and fix. My fix  was
> cl/23536069,
> which I guess I should have committed manually instead of going through the
> commit queue, my apologies.


Ah, sorry, I hadn't seen this. I should have thought of checking your
pending CLs.


> BTW, is there any documentation about things like
> this (don't use <iostream>?). It's pretty annoying to get reverted even
> after
> passing all the trybots.
>

I guess there's
https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=94794which might
count as documentation?

Checking for static initializers on tryjobs is a bit tricky, see
https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=110002 for why.


>
> https://chromiumcodereview.**appspot.com/23891006/<https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/23891006/>
>

subject: Fix a static initializer regression.
